doc.after: The rapid industrialisation of the English economy cost many craft workers their jobs The movement started first with lace and hosiery workers near Nottingham and spread to other areas of the textile industry owing to early industrialisation Many weavers also found themselves suddenly unemployed since they could no longer compete with machines which only required relatively limited and unskilled labour to produce more cloth than a single weaver Many such unemployed workers weavers and others turned their animosity towards the machines that had taken their jobs and began destroying factories and machinery These attackers became known as Luddites supposedly followers of Ned Ludd a folklore figure The first attacks of the Luddite movement began in 1811 The Luddites rapidly gained popularity and the British government took drastic measures using the militia or army to protect industry Those rioters who were caught were tried and hanged or transported for life
